reviews.comment_grading:
6.67%      Class participation
16.67%    2 Topic essays of 200 words
6.66%      In-class activity
2%           Research credit
25%         Group Project & Presentation
15%         Peer Evaluation

The grading system is non-transparent as you only receive for score for your work. The grading system listed in the course syllabus for the essays are extremely vague.

Class participation is easy to achieve as all it takes is switching on the mic and talking about something vaguely related to the content of the lecture.

The group formed in the beginning of the semester will be your group for the in-class activity and the group project, so finding someone you can trust to do some good work is recommended if you want to get a good grade out of this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload for this course is acceptable.
The 2 essays of 200 words each takes little time to complete and plenty of time is given to complete them.

The in-class activity takes up one lecture and it wasn't too difficult as long as you have a functioning group. My group encountered
some time constrain because one of my groupmate decided to do nothing during the activity.

The workload for group project and presentation is manageable. A 5 page report and a 13 minute presentation for a group of 5 is quite light as long as your groupmates are willing to contribute. The hardest part of the group project is to think of a idea that the professor approves of.

The quiz is closed book with MC questions and a 200 word essay question.

reviews.author: procrastinator
reviews.comment_content: The content is really straightforward, pretty vague and general so it's simple to understand. There are readings assigned (mostly news articles) that might help with the content. But overall the content was pretty boring for me, I only found certain topics like politics and marketing interesting because it had more controversial and engaging discussions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Coral is a pretty decent professor, she's quite engaging and tries to start discussions every class to give students an opportunity to participate. She also allows you to participate via typing in the zoom chatbox if you aren't comfortable with speaking out loud which was nice. She is a pretty unconventional professor, sometimes drops a shit or f-bomb here and there but overall a chill and enjoyable class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 6.67%
Two 200-word Essays 16.67% - 2.5/3 (mean 2.7) and 3/3 (mean 2.4)
In-class activities 6.66% - 10/10 Mean 7.8
Research Credit 2% - 2/2
Group Project (report and presentation) 25% - Report 10/10 (mean 7.8), Presentation 9/10 (mean 7.5)
Peer Evaluation 15%
Final Exam (Quiz, MCQ and Short Essay Question) 28% - 20/30

Final Grade: A-

Overall the grading is good, just make sure you work hard on the project because she does weigh it heavily. The peer evaluation is also really important so make sure you're not free-riding or else your grade is going to take a hit.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty light as long as you work on the group project progressively. The report is pretty easy because it's short, and you can be creative with the formatting and such. Coral doesn't give you any guidance on what the content should be so you have to work it out on your own with your group. Also, if you're an SBM student she has higher expectations for you. You can actually pick your team (a group of 5) so if you have friends taking the course with you that would be an advantage, because if not you're going to be assigned a team. The final exam (closed book) is basically just all of the content along with a bunch of MCQ questions and a short essay style question. If you just revise through the ppt slides + readings it's more than enough to revise for, but the short-answer question was a little more abstract because she doesn't say much about it until the end of the semester so try to ask for more examples to get a better understanding of how to do it.

reviews.author: Edr
reviews.comment_content:
This course introduced us to the world of marketing, particularly its strategies and principles, through peering into how companies are stakeholders in revolving around social issues.

In fact, regardless of being a consumer or a manager or a producer, we have to realize that marketing strategies or decisions are intertwined with social issues or trends. For example, fast fashion companies including H&M, which itself is a contributor of polluting ecosystems, intend to appeal to conscious consumers by propagating greenwashing strategies.

In the end, this course aims to expose us to the importance of corporation social responsibility and  the presence of socially accountable companies that turn a profit.

Content:
Marketing and Fashion
Marketing and Food
From Greenwashing to Cause Marketing
Marketing and recycling
Marketing and Mindful consumption
Marketing and Climate crisis
Marketing and Political Propaganda
Coolness : basic consumer psychology
Marketing and sin goods and travel
Marketing and social business
Marketing and Social Media
Marketing and Education
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor is experienced in marketing in the context of social issues and phenomena, and has strong economic and analytic background knowledge.

During lectures, we were encouraged to not only master fundamental marketing theories, but also speak up on our viewpoints toward a particular topic, and exposing each other to different viewpoints and insights.

However, some lectures might be taught with biased content or opinion from both students or the instructor, especially with regards to politics or education, which were taught in class.

All about daily work.

|--- Online class participation : 6.67%
|--- 200 word topic essay x 2 : 11.67%

Peer evaluation: 13%

reviews.author: Studdas
reviews.title: Course Review of MARK 1220
reviews.comment_content:
This course throws light over how businesses have an impact on society and how they should be more responsible for their actions. It challenges the dynamics of marketing and the role it now plays within a social, sustainable and/or ethical context.
It is quite interesting to see how marketing plays such a huge role environmentally.
The course also focusses on environmental issues and how marketing can be used as a tool to help the environment.
reviews.comment_teaching:
1. She is super excited and passionate about marketing and the course.
2. Since she is an adjunct professor she has her own firm which integrates meaning and purpose in a company's DNA, this means that she invites influential people for guest lectures.
3. She is always there to help you when you need help with a project or just career advice for marketing.
Overall, it was great fun. Real-life examples are used and every student voices their opinion. She makes you feel comfortable by telling you that there is no right answer motivating people to participate more.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was very good for me. I attended most of the classes, participated a lot and she loved our group project. (A)
Class Participation - 13%
Research Credit - 2%
Group Project & Presentation - 40%
Peer Evaluation - 10%
Quiz - 35%
You have to participate in class, which means she has to know your name and write it down in the sheet which is passed around so she is aware of how much you participate in class.
The Group Project and Quiz are the most important for you to score well.
The quiz is fairly easy. If you attend class and read the slides you should be good to go.
No attendance, but it is recommended.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload was pretty light.
It all boils down to the group project and your quiz. I had a great group and work was equally split so it was easy.
You can just prepare one day before the quiz and score well.

reviews.comment_content:

Topic 5: Marketing and Politics
Topic 6: Cigarettes and Alcohol

Copied from other contributors of the same semester.

The content matches the title of the course -- marketing and society. All of the topics are linked with the society that we are living it. Don't expect to learn marketing concepts or skillset from this course. Since this course is more about our daily shopping habits/behaviors, and how we make choices, how are choices are being effected by marketing. Overall, it is a "blowing water" course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Coral has a strong accent, which needs a week to get familiarize. She doesn't teach according to her powerpoints/schedule, therefore attending the class is important as the powerpoint doesn't cover most of the things she said in class (also for participation marks). The course schedule was changed at least 3 times throughout the semester (sometimes without prior notice!!!). She is also very emotional, her decision varies with her emotion. Be prepared for the everchanging schedule.

The TA was nice and can answer our questions with cantonese/mandarin/english, but she seems not familiar with Canvas as I seldom receives announcement notifications, need to check myself on canvas regularly... ==

reviews.comment_workload:
For a science student, workload is light.
Even though I had 2 freeriders who DID NOT contribute ideas to the presentation, the workload was manageable. The hardest part was to think of an idea for the project which Coral approves.  

DON'T be a deadline fighter since the deadline of the assignments can be changed with just a few days notice, or hours.

Attend the classes for guidelines on the projects since she will NOT give you any templates and samples will only be shown in class. Consultation session will be within class time whenever Carol feels like it (No prior notice as always).

If you are a person who don't like frequently changing schedules, this course is not for you.

reviews.author: Gloria Borger
reviews.comment_content:
Due to this course being a common core course, the professor seldom or never taught us marketing terminologies, so non-business students can take this course with no problem as there are no major disadvantages.

The course materials are designed to make the students a better consumer by learning how marketing can heavily influence one's choice when making consumption choices. It also covers how marketing can solve social problems.

Generally, I think the content is quite interesting, topics such as fast-fashion and advertisements are closely related to our daily lives and we can realize how marketing plays a big role in it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lessons are quite fun. The professor is very down to earth, funny, and encouraging. (Tho her accent isn't really that easy to listen to).
She doesn't really like to follow the slides and rather prefer encouraging students to exchange opinions. Also, she really likes to play some videos to explain the topics as well.
She also invited guest speakers once every few weeks to give presentations about the projects/companies they are working on.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation 13%
Research credit 2%
Group project & Presentation 40%
Peer evaluation 10%
Quiz 35%

Participation matters quite a lot during the class. Every time you raise a question or answer a question, you have to write down your name on the paper distributed in order to count how many times you have done it throughout the semester. If you participate 15 times or more in class, you get the full marks of it.

However, the grading isn't very transparent, I don't really know any of my marks so I can't tell whether my grade is reasonable or not. I got a B anyways. I guess it's ok considering how little effort I put into it.
reviews.comment_workload: Almost no workload except the group project, which you don't need to put too much effort into it as well if you have okay groupmates.

reviews.author: toxicboi
reviews.title: This course changed my life!
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course is extremely relevant as it takes us through a journey of how important marketing is in our lives, and how it has shaped our world today. We start by talking about how marketing has made this world a terrible place, and how we can use marketing to fix it.

There is a huge emphasis on sustainability and social good. We cover topics like Marketing practices in Fashion, Meat, Politics, F&B industries. There are some excellent professional guest speakers who come and give their perspective about the course content.

This content influenced and inspired me to change the way I behave in my daily life, from decreasing my meat intake to vowing never to buy from fast fashion companies and actively practising recycling.

There are also many real-world case studies which are up to date so, we can keep up based on whatever is happening around us. We also watch a lot of advertisements, ted talks and speeches during the class.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Puig is one of the best professors I have studied under in HKUST. She is a working professional who could be doing anything else, but she chooses to spend her time teaching and mentoring students, which is quite awesome of her.

She is very approachable, you can even talk to her about Game of Thrones after class. And she always invites students to networking events where you could get internships.

If you take this class, make sure to create a meaningful connection with her, it could be very beneficial to you.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation - 13%
The professor emphasises on participation in class. Even though it is not compulsory, I would highly recommend going to all classes and speaking whatever is on your mind. The professor loves answering questions and engaging with the students.

Marketing Surveys - 2%

Group Project & Presentation - 40%
This is probably the most important part of the course. It is very exciting to work on. We are required to create some social awareness on an issue within HKUST that related to one of the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Feel free to discuss your ideas with the professor, and pick up on hints about what she is looking for.

Peer Evaluation - 10%
Don't freeride, and report free riders.

Final Quiz - 35%
The best way to 'study' for the quiz is to attend each class, pay attention and engage with the content. If you do that, you can honestly walk into the final without any preparation and still score full marks.

I ended up getting an A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
As long as you attend all classes, the workload is quite minimal.

You have almost 2 months for the final presentation and report, so if you pace it right, it will be a breeze!
